sections.content: Part 1: The High Cost of Dwelling

Your brain is a poor office manager. When you encounter a problem—a conflict at work, a leaky tap, a stalled project—your mind tends to “dwell.” It loops the problem repeatedly in your working memory, trying to solve it with brute force worry.

Unify breaks this loop using a Structured Input Template. By forcing you to fill out specific fields, the interface acts as a cognitive container. You stop “dwelling” on the abstract worry and start “defining” the concrete parameters.
In the heat of the moment, every problem feels like a catastrophe. A missed email feels just as stressful as a missed mortgage payment because our emotional brain struggles to differentiate scale.
Unify demands an Objective Difficulty Rating (1–5 Stars). This forces your logical brain to intervene. “Is this actually a disaster, or just a nuisance?”
We often assume we will remember our lessons, but we don’t. The insight you gain during a stressful Tuesday is often gone by a relaxing Saturday.
Unify acts as an External Memory Core. It allows you to “catch” experiences the moment they occur, building a database of your own life.

Solving problems returns you to zero. To go above zero—to achieve mastery—you need a trajectory. The Harada Grid breaks a massive 5-year vision into 8 sub-goals, and those sub-goals into daily habits. It turns the “impossible” into the “inevitable.”

True self-analysis requires a sanctuary. You cannot be honest about your financial fears or personal failings if you believe a server is logging your keystrokes. Unify is built on Browser Storage Architecture.
